titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: In ranging round my grounds every morning, not a day passes, but I meet with some new phenomenon of vegetation, the observation of which ought to be accompanied and immediately followed by examination and meditation— It never is, and however mortifying to my self-conceit it may be, I am constrained to confess that the faculty of combining ideas and brooding over them till they fructify, hasn if not totally denied to me, imparted in scanty measure.— I took John Kirk round my seedling nurseries this morning and shewed him the trees that are, and those that are not to be taken up— I have now from the acorn, the black, white, red, and chesnut Oaks of considerable size, besides the English white Oaks which bear acorns in profusion. None of the native trees have yet borne fruit— Our red cherries are now so far ripened that we had yesterday and this day tarts made of them— The trees throw up suckers which bear transplanting and are of rapid growth, but I have never raised a cherry, except the mazzard, or a plum from the stone— This day there was a very light easterly breeze which made the day comfortable. I wrote further upon my Letter to Bangor, but did not finish it— Read a chapter in Dr Ware’s inquiry. His second chapter is on the sources from which the proofs of Religion and its truths are to be drawn.— These are Nature, and Revelation.— “The being of God, including all his attributes—the moral government of God, and a future life of righteous retribution”— To these articles may be reduced, and in them included—[“]all that we know of religion by the light of Nature.”— Creation is indeed to the mind of man evidence of a creator—but is it evidence of his moral government— This is not clear— Still less is it evidence of future righteous retribution— The visible creation evinces order—but not moral government, or future retribution— In the progress of human reason man conceives the idea of justice; and the family relations teach sympathy— With the idea of God therefore is connected in one indissoluble chain those of power, justice and mercy; and from them are deduced those of moral government and future retribution— Still the continued existence of man after death is so contrary to all the evidence of the senses, that it must rest forever on the pillars of Faith— I have too long intermitted the monthly summary of my daily occupations— In the month of June just expired I have risen at an earlier average than 4— Go up the hill to see the Sunrise from the South-east corner of my son’s house with one of the most magnificent spectacles of nature in the scenery before me— I then loiter about my grounds two hours or more. Return to my chamber and receive the mail except on Sundays. Breakfast at 8. Read newspapers and Letters, and write till 1/2 past 2. dine—Siesta—ride with my daughter in the carriage—up the hill to see the Sunset— No Evening

A day of intense heat. Mr Lunt who has been with his wife upon a fortnights excursion into the Country returned home yesterday, and preached this morning from Ephesians 6 13 “Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.” The discourse was a very earnest exhortation, to resist all manner of temptation— It was a very serious and sensible dissertation upon a duty which every Christian is called very frequently called to perform— The Lord’s prayer supplicates the almighty not to lead us into temptation; which implies that temptation itself comes from the agency of God himself, and seems to imply that from the weakness and frailty of our Nature we are not able to resist a temptation when it comes.— The Scripture says that the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, and in another place that the Lord gave the children of Israel Statutes that were not good. But if the Lord leads men into temptation, who can redeem them from it?— This is one of the mysteries for future solution— It cannot be accounted for here— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with me. Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from Psalm 101.1. [“]I will sing of mercy and judgment; unto thee, O Lord will I sing.”— The Sermon was a sort of critical and historical Essay upon the book of Psalms— A subject upon which there is much to be said— I would consider it first as the only model of Hebrew Lyric Poetry. 2. compare it with the Lyric Poetry of the Greeks and Romans. 3. It exclusive character devotional— 4. connected with the religious worship of the tabernacle and afterwards of the temple— The musical establishment of David connected with the composition of the Psalms. 5. The effect of music, vocal and instrumental, upon religious worship. 6. Peculiarly suited to the worship of one God— Creator and Preserver of the world— The adaptation of sacred music and Psalms, to Christian worship.— Mr Lunt gave out to be sung after the Sermon his 57th hymn, which is Watts’s version of the 33d. psalm—one of the poorest that Watts ever composed—in which he makes ways rhyme with grace, loves with proves, spread with made, and seas with place; all in three Stanzas— It ought not to have been admitted into his collection— There was a collection taken up according to the annual usage for the Sunday school library. The S.S. Westerly gale, burning hot blew till the going down of the Sun, and then came on a very light thunder shower Mr Degrand left us to return to Boston shortly before nine— I attempted a versification of the 33d Psalm but only accomplished it in part— The Great Western Steamer arrived yesterday at New-York from Liverpool, and brought News from London to the 17th. of June.

The Sun rose beclouded, and the weather was nearly as warm, as last evening immediately after the shower which was very light— I visited my seedling trees and wasted two hours in digging round them, manuring the land; and coaxing the small ones to grow— In the meantime a fresh breeze from the Northwest swept off all the clouds and compelled me to resume my winter garments. Mr Caleb Cushing Commissioner Plenipotentiary to China, and Joseph Vance heretofore a member of Congress from the State of Ohio, and afterwards Governor of that State paid me a morning visit, before breakfast; and subsequently the Revd. Samuel K. Lothrop, with Mr Ezekiel Bacon of Utica New-York— Cushing’s visit would have surprized me, but that he had told my Son last Friday that he intended to make it— He has not made his Court to Captain Tyler in vain. His obsequiousness and sacrifice of principle lost him the favour of his Constituents who repudiated him at the recent elections, but Mr Tyler had more precious favours in his gift, and he has lavished them in profusion upon Cushing. He is to embark in a few days for Alexandria in Egypt—to proceed thence overland to Bombay; where he is to find the Steamer Missouri, which is to take him to Canton— Mr Vance has within a few years experienced also the fickleness of popular favour— He was originally a poor labourer, but rose by his eloquence to Congress and to the Government of the State, and then was dropped into his primitive obscurity— Corwin is such an other, with more talent but not with deeper root. Ezekiel Bacon can tell much the same tale— He was a member of Congress from Berkshire, Massachusetts at the time of Jefferson’s embargo. Afterwards moved into the State of New-York, and engaged deeply in her politics—but has been many years an invalid; retired altogether from public life, and writing verses in a sick chamber at Utica— My correspondence with him began in 1808. and I have several Letters from him with enclosed poetry within the last year— I had not seen him since I went to Russia, and did not know him even when named to me by Mr Lothrop till the course of conversation disclosed who he was.— Archibald Macon (his Surname I forgot[)] is a black man who says he has been studying Law these two years, and is raising a contribution to enable him to go to Hayti or to Jamaica. I rode to Milton this afternoon with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs Charles and her baby Arthur— I received this morning a Letter from my wife, with information that Johnson Hellen—his wife andchildren have been poisoned with Arsenic steeped in their coffee at breakfast by an Irishwoman— I finished this Evening my Letter to Bangor.

I saw the Sun rise from the corner of Charles’s house and marked its bearing, in the centre of the valley between the two hills.— I took the usual morning range round my grounds with no new observations on my trees—save the appearance of 8 or ten seedling English Oaks within a circle of 6 feet round the spot in the garden where one of those trees had been set out and grew and bore last year many acorns— It was taken up last Autumn, and these seedlings are from self-planted acorns which had fallen from the tree, and were left unnoticed on the ground—

My only surviving Son, Charles Francis, delivered the annual Boston City Oration on the Anniversary of Independence; an incident of the most intense interest to me, it being this day fifty years, since I performed the same service to the town. At half past 8 this morning we left my gate, and went into Boston; alighting at the city Hall in School Street, where we found the Mayor of the City, Martin Brimmer; and the Aldermen, common council with the other City Officers were assembling for a procession— President Quincy and Captain John Percival were among the persons whom I met there— Soon after 10. the procession moved escorted by two military companies to Faneuil Hall, where for the first time this celebration was held. It has usually been at the Old South Church, and was there in 1793 when I performed— The order of performances this day was 1. Music. 2 An Ode, by a select choir of pupils of the public schools, under the direction of Lowell Mason 3. Prayer, by the Revd Mr Hague. 4. Selections from the Scriptures by the Revd. Mr Gray.— 5. Ode written by Mrs L. H. Sigourney. 6. Oration by Charles Francis Adams 7. Prayer, by the Revd. Mr Gray. 8. Hymn—To the tune of God save the king. 9. Benediction by Mr Hague. The Oration occupied one hour and a quarter in the delivery; and was received with great, repeated and long continued applause— The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, with a very respectable and highly intelligent auditory. There was a station assigned in the procession to the members of the Massachusetts delegation in Congress; in which I walked with Robert C. Winthrop. Neither Governor Morton nor any member of his Council was present.— About a quarter past one, the ceremonies were all over— I went with Charles and Dr Frothingham to his house, where our Carriage soon came and took Charles and me home to Quincy. Mrs Frothingham with two of her sons and two daughters, came from Boston, and dined at Charles’s— I dined with only Louisa C. Smith. The last time I had been in Boston on the 4th. of July was in 1809. I went up the hill at Sunset. Mrs Frothingham returned with her children to Boston— We witnessed the fireworks on the Common of Boston. No language can express the agitation of my feelings, and the remembrances of this day [symbols]

The morning was cloudy, and there were copious showers in the forenoon. But soon after the sky was swept clear with a Northwest wind rather cold than cool. In my morning visitation to my trees I still found something to observe. I took off a girdle of suckers round an old Russet apple tree in the lane between my house and Charles’s; and I tied to the old dead stem two shoots of a black Jack Oak which has been growing twelve years in the Nursery; which throws up every summer shoots four or five feet high, and die down almost to the ground every winter— I have thus nearly ascertained that the Cork, Willow, and live-Oak, will not bear this climate— I fear the blackjack, will share the same fate; but I hope the English white-Oak may be propagated by the Acorn to any extent. Of a dozen acorns from the nursery trees, which I sowed last October, in a row close to the kitchen garden gate, last Thursday I perceived that one was breaking through the surface of the ground, and now at the end of a week, the plumelet is about half an inch above ground in the form of miniature leaves— This morning I perceived a second and this afternoon a third of the same row piercing through the soil— I sowed about the same time last autumn a number of shagbark walnuts, not one of which yet appears. Probably the reason why so many seedlings from this hard nut are winter-killed the first season after they come up is because they come up so late in the summer that they have not time to harden into wood before the sharp frosts set in—and I propose a double experiment to see if the vegetation of them cannot be hastened or retarded; by sowing from the 15th. to the 20th of October 3 rows of one dozen each 1. of nuts in the shell. 2. of nuts with the shell cracked. 3. of nuts in the drupe.— Another experiment may be to sow one row on the 1st. of October and another on the first of November— I find a multitude of new hatched slug worms eroding the surface of my cherry tree and pear tree leaves— Fresh spurs are putting forth from button-wood trees and stakes which were apparently dead— There came a man apparently 60 years of age, in very coarse apparel with red hair and a weather-beaten face, who said he was a Virginia named Richard Bland Randolph— That he had received in 1798 a midshipman’s warrant from my father; had been one of the captors of the French frigate L’Insurgente; and had been dismissed from the service at the reduction of the Navy by Mr Jefferson in 1802. That he had now a petition before congress for prize money of which he had never lifted the first cent; that he had made himself odious in Virginia by expressing opinions in favour of abolition; and that he had not bread to eat— I rode this afternoon to Milton with Louisa C Smith, Mrs Charles, and her boy Arthur—

I emptied this morning one of my flower pots; filled it with fresh earth from the garden and sowed in it the seeds of a Baldwin apple which had been kept sound through the winter, but which has been decaying since my return home on my library mantle piece—and with them I sowed one dozen red cherry stones of cherries just now ripe and which I picked from the trees— My last experiment to see if they will vegetate.— I leave my trees. My Son went this morning to Cambridge to attend a greek examination. At 10. O’Clock, I left home with his wife, and her Son John Quincy—we went into Boston, and dined at Dr Frothingham’s; meeting there her father Mr Peter Chardon Brooks— Immediately after dinner we proceeded to the depot of the Western Railroad, where after taking leave of Charles who had just come in from Cambridge, we started in the Cars at half past 3.— The weather was fine—clear sunshine yet comfortably cool— We passed through the towns of Natick, Southborough—Westborough, Worcester, Brookfield— Charlton and several others which I neglected to ascertain, and at a quarter before 9. landed at Warriner’s United States Hotel in Springfield 96 miles from Boston— Among our travelling companions were the Revd. Alexander Young, Minister of the New South Church, Boston; going by the way of Hartford and New-Haven, to preach two Sundays at New-York. Mr and Mrs Joseph Grinnell of New-Bedford and Mr Henry Sargent, going to visit his son, settled at Newburgh opposite to Fishkill landing on Hudson’s river— The Season is delightful. The face of the Country like the garden of Eden— It is the Season of hay-making and throughout our way, the mower with his scythe, the cocking of the grass, or the spreading it from the cock to dry, followed in alternate succession, and the atmosphere was charged only with varieties of fragrance— Fields of Indian corn, Rye, Potatoes and Oats interchangeably with pastures covered with grazing cattle, neat and comfortable houses and kitchen gardens and Orchards laden with ripening fruit, attested a genial climate a fruitful Season and a region of Peace, plenty and contentment— As the cars flew along from Boston till we passed through Natick the contrast of the Seasons crowded upon my observation between the present aspect of the country, and that which I witnessed last November when I went to deliver the Lecture, with the ice glazed road to Mr Wilson’s house, and the falling snow of the next morning as I returned to Boston— At Springfield we took our lodging for the night at Jeremy Warriner’s United States Hotel, one of the most elegant houses of public entertainment that I ever visited— This morning, I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and invited his daughter Mary to go out to Quincy, and pass a few days with her Aunt Louisa C. Smith till my return, but her health is so bad that she declined going from home.

Mr Young departed at 7 this morning in a Steamer for Hartford— Mr Sargent disappeared in another direction for Hudson’s river. I rose with the Sun, and wrote in my bed chamber till breakfast time at 8. having no time to examine a narrative of an expedition to the Oregon territory in 1835, 36 and 37. by Dr Samuel Parker or the life of the Revd. Lemuel Haynes a Mulatto minister of the gospel, born in 1753 and deceased in 1833. of whom I had never heard before; but who was many years eminent as a preacher in Connecticut and the western part of the State of New-York. Books which I found on the table at which I wrote— After breakfast, Coll. Howard and Mr Ashmun called to see us; and accompanied Mr Brooks and myself with John Quincy to the Arsenal and the armoury. At the Arsenal we saw 30000 stands of arms, and were told that there were 150,000 ready for use in case of need— At the armoury Major Ripley went round with us, and we saw the various processes of making the gun barrels, and the black walnut gun stocks— I had seen these processes in 1828, but they are constantly making improvements in the manipulation of the musketry— They are now substituting the percussion lock and cap for the flint lock and pan—but Major Ripley told me that unless an appropriation should be very shortly made to repair or rather to rebuild the house over the water fall, in which they make the gun barrels and stocks he apprehends it will crumble into ruin and carry the workmen employed in it with it— On our return to Warriner’s we had a visit from Mr William B. Calhoun, and Mrs Grinnell was visited by her two Sisters Mrs Dalton and Mrs Bentley— We had a magnificent collation dinner, and at one O’Clock rode to the depot and resumed our seats in the railroad Cars— There was a light sprinkling of rain but the clouds gradually dispersed and the Evening was fine— Mr and Mrs Grinnell were still with us to Pittsfield 54. miles, through a country contrasting with that through which we had passed yesterday— A wild region of dark forests and stupendous rocks, through many of which deep cuts and inclined plains, have been made for the Western railroad, which has cost ten millions of dollars. At Pittsfield we quitted the railroad and bid farewell to Mr and Mrs Grinnell and our new acquaintance Mr Porter of Lee a member of Governor Marcus Morton’s Council—we took a Carriage and came in two hours to Lebanon Springs over a heavy mountainous road. Here we are to pass three or four days, for the sake of the baths, said to be salubrious. We expected to have met here my old Classmate judge Samuel Putnam, and Mr Caleb Loring of Boston, but were disappointed. They went away this morning— Mr Charles G. Loring is here with his wife, a daughter of judge Putnam, and a son and daughter—and Mrs Crowninshield another daughter of judge Putnam.

The Columbian Hall at the Lebanon Springs, the house at which we have taken our lodgings, is a Hotel kept by Hull and Bentley, with about 120 bed chambers on four low Stories of a wooden mansion with a wide piazza round three sides of the house on the second and third Stories— A large dining hall on the ground floor with a reading and bar room over which ascending a flight of steps there is also a large drawing room— The house is built on the eastern side of a high and steep hill, in the form of a half rectangle the short side of which fronts the street, and the long side a very extensive valley between two ranges of lofty mountains chiefly covered with Oak, chesnut, beech—birch, black walnut and especially sugar maple trees, interspersed with willows and sycamores of respectable size and stature but none of them very large or tall— The sumach, and locust are also very common among them.— On rising this morning and walking round the piazza, I was much struck by the successive lights and shades of the Sun rising in a crystal clear sky, gilding the tops of the mountains successively in proportion to their respective elevations piercing through interstitial passages between the hills into parts of the valley, and casting long dark shades of solitary trees in one direction before them—for three quarters of an hour the peaks of the mountains were taking one after another the golden tinge, before the sunbeam became visible from the piazzo, on which I was walking, and listening to the morning concert of the birds. This was very little varied by the spring and yellow birds, with the king-bird, wren, swallow and robin— None, but what I hear at Quincy, and no sound either of bobolink or quail.— I wrote till breakfast time at 8 and soon after with all our party, a Mr Aymer and two Ladies from New-York, and Edward, a son of Patrick Jackson I rode in two Carriages up the hills to a tower about 50 feet high on the loftiest summit of this neighbourhood, whence we had a range of prospect round the compass with a radius of fifty miles.— The line between the States of New-York and Massachusetts is on the road from Lebanon to the tower which is in Berkshire County, and whence parts of the States of Massachusetts, New-Hampshire, Vermont and New-York are visible at one view— Returning from the tower, at Noon, I took a bath: Water at 90. not warm. After dinner I had a visit from Mr Dunham and Mr Hayden of Pittsfield to invite me there; but I declined— Mr Dunham brought with him his daughter Helen Maria’s Album for me to write my name in it— We next rode, taking with us a small boy a son of Mrs Crowninshield, to the village of the Shakers, and visited a man named John Mantle, and a woman living in two rooms of one house, where they keep a small shop of Shakerism, at unconscionable prices. we saw also their dairy, and cheeses and cow-yard with two women, milking 25 cows— Returned, and after tea, spent the Evening on the Piazza, in converse with a cluster of Strangers.
